title: Montgomery County officials remind drivers of no right turn on red areas
description: The law, which went into effect on July 1, states that designated downtown and town center areas in the county will now prohibit right turns at red traffic light areas.
content:
MONTGOMERY COUNTY, Md. (DC News Now) — Montgomery County officials are issuing a reminder to drivers about designated areas where right turns at red traffic signals are prohibited.

The law, which went into effect on July 1, states that designated downtown and town center areas in the county will now prohibit right turns at red traffic light areas.

It is part of the Safe Streets Act of 2023, a bill that aims to “improve pedestrian and cyclist safety on Montgomery County roadways,” according to a news release.

These intersections include ones in Bethesda, Friendship Heights, Silver Spring, Wheaton, Germantown, Glenmont, Twinbrook and White Flint. Officials said that more than 200 “No Right Turns on Red” signs have been placed at these designated intersections.

The Montgomery County Department of Transportation said that it started installing these signs over the summer and has since completed installation.

Road worker struck by car on MD 200 in Silver Spring: Officials

“We are eliminating right turns at red lights in our busy downtown areas where we know many residents walk, bike, or scooter to shops, restaurants, and other amenities,” County Executive Marc Elrich said in the news release. “With the Safe Streets Act, we are taking action to ensure our streets are safe for pedestrians and cyclists when going to school, to work, or while enjoying our downtown areas. I was pleased to sign into law this bill, which was passed unanimously by County Council.”

“Too many residents are being injured while lawfully crossing the street, with nearly 60% of all pedestrian- and cyclist-involved crashes occurring at intersections,” Councilmember Evan Glass, Chair of the Transportation and Environment Committee, said in the release.

Glass took the lead in introducing and spearheading the legislation.

Neighboring districts — including D.C. and parts of Arlington, Va. — have similar restrictions on right turns at red lights.
